Regioselective hydrophosphorylation of alkynes by a functionalized heterogeneous Cu-chitosan based catalyst Yining Ren Data curation Liyong Chen Data curation Mingyu Xie Data curation Shipan Xu Investigation Data curation Yu Liu Conceptualization Longzhi Zhu Writing – original draft ⁎ Weifeng Xu Writing – review & editing ⁎ Biquan Xiong Writing – review & editing Conceptualization ⁎ Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan Institute of Science and Technology, Yueyang 414006, PR China Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan Institute of Science and Technology Yueyang 414006 PR China Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan Institute of Science and Technology, Yueyang, 414006, P R China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. The functionalized heterogeneous Cu-chitosan based catalyst was developed for the regioselective hydrophosphorylation of alkynes with secondary H-phosphine oxides. The functionalized chitosan framework was produced through a cross-coupling reaction between chitosan and 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine. Following this, the coordination of Cu(OAc)2 with the functionalized chitosan framework led to the synthesis of the heterogeneous Cu-chitosan based catalyst. Various techniques, such as powder FT-IR spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 physical adsorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), were employed to characterize the catalyst. Subsequently, the resulting Cu(OAc)2@chitosan@2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine catalyst exhibited remarkable catalytic activity in the regioselective hydrophosphorylation of alkynes with the formation of P–C bonds, displaying exceptional E/Z selectivity. This successful catalysis led to the synthesis of a range of (E) anti-Markovnikov adducts with high yields. The catalyst shows high recyclability in this transformation. On the basis of step-by-step control experiments, a plausible mechanism is proposed. Graphical Abstract Keywords P–H bonds Construction of P–C bonds Hydrophosphorylation Heterogeneous catalysis Anti-Markovnikov addition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Organophosphorus compounds are widely used in catalysis, medicinal chemistry, coordination chemistry, materials and organic synthesis. [1] In particular, owing to the unique biological and pharmacological activities of alkenyl functionalized organophosphorus compounds, construction of the P–C bonds for the synthesis of these compounds is of great interest and particular importance. [2] Traditionally, the formation of P–C bonds for alkenylphosphine oxides involves transition metal-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions of H-phosphine oxides (P(O)–H) with alkenyl halides in the presence of a base. [3] Another effective method is the oxidative decarboxylative hydrophosphorylation of cinnamic acids with H-phosphine oxides to generate alkenylphosphoryl compounds. [4] A notable advancement in this field was made in 2014 by Gao et al., who introduced a novel copper-catalyzed protocol for the decarboxylative coupling of alkynyl acids with P(O)H compounds to synthesize (E)-1-alkenylphosphine oxides. [5] Furthermore, the transition metal-catalyzed dehydrogenative coupling reaction of H-phosphine oxides with olefins presents an effective route for the synthesis of alkenylphosphoryl compounds. [6] However, despite the significance of these methods, challenges such as the use of oxidants, bases, poor atomic economy, and environmental unfriendliness remain prevalent ( Scheme 1). The metal-catalyzed addition of H-phosphine oxides to an unsaturated carbon-carbon triple bonds is an efficient and simple method for producing alkenyl phosphine oxides, utilizing a variety of metals such as Pd, [7] Cu, [8] Rh, [9] Ni, [10] Co, [11] La, [12] etc. [13] In 2007, Zhao and Fu et al. reported a copper-catalyzed additions of P(O)–H compounds to alkynes, resulting in high regio- and stereoselective generation of E-alkenylphosphine oxides. [14] Lei et al. also contributed to the field by disclosing an Ag-promoted oxidative cross-coupling reaction between terminal alkynes and secondary phosphine oxides. [15] Subsequently, in 2018, Han et al. introduced a novel palladium-catalyzed hydrophosphorylation of alkynes with P(O)–H compounds, leading to the production of Markovnikov adducts in high yields with excellent regioselectivity. [7a] While significant progress has been made in selective hydrophosphorylation of alkynes in homogeneous catalytic systems, studies on heterogeneous catalysis remain limited. In this context, a novel heterogeneous Cu-chitosan based catalyst was developed to synthesize anti-Markovnikov products of (E)-alkenylphosphoryl compounds through regioselective hydrophosphorylation of alkynes, facilitating P–C bond formation. Particularly noteworthy is that this transformation eliminates the need for noble metal catalysts, additional ligands and bases. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of chitosan-framework Chitosan (deacetylation ≥ 95 %, viscosity: 100–200 mPa·s, 1.0 g), 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (1.0 g), and K2CO3 (3.0 g) were added in acetone (50 mL) and heated at 100 °C for 24 h under an air atmosphere. After the reaction, HCl aqueous was added to neutralize the excess K2CO3. The resulting solid was washed with water and acetone for three times (10 mL/time), respectively, dried under vacuum to afford the corresponding chitosan@2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (yellow powder). 2.2 Synthesis of [Cu]@CTT catalyst Chitosan@2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (1.0 g) and Cu(OAc)2·H2O (1.0 g) were stirred in acetone (50 mL) at 60 °C for 24 hours under an air atmosphere. After the completion of the reaction, the resulting solid material was subjected to a series of washing steps. The solid was first rinsed twice with 10 mL of water and then with 10 mL of acetone. Following the washing steps, the solid was dried under vacuum to obtain the final product, a green powder identified as Cu(OAc)2@chitosan@2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine, and is commonly referred to as [Cu]@CTT. 2.3 General considerations All solvents used in the reactions were freshly distilled. The other reagents were recrystallized or distilled as necessary. 1H (400 MHz), 13C{1H} (100 MHz), 31P{1H} (160 MHz) and 19F{1H} (376 MHz) were recorded on a 400 MHz spectrometer in CDCl3. 1H NMR chemical shifts were reported using TMS as the internal standard while 13C{1H} NMR chemical shifts were reported relative to CDCl3. The electron ionization method was used for HRMS measurements, and the mass analyzer type was double-focusing. 2.4 General procedure for the preparation of (E) anti-Markovnikov adducts A mixture of P–H compounds (0.2 mmol), alkynes (0.2 mmol), and [Cu]@CTT (10 mg) was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (1.0 mL) and stirred under N2 atmosphere at 100 °C for 12 h. Removal of the solvent under a reduced pressure gave the crude product. Pure product was obtained by passing the crude product through a short silica gel column using hexane/EtOAc (1:1–1:2) as eluent. 3 Results and discussion Organic carriers, such as chitosan, offer advantages over traditional heterogeneous catalytic systems compared with inorganic carriers. Chitosan, a polysaccharide compound derived from various sources and biodegradable, possesses multiple easily modifiable groups, making it well-suited for chelating metals. Despite its poor solubility in most organic solvents, chitosan can be easily treated through incineration or carbonization methods after catalyst deactivation, allowing for the production of single atom catalysts, thereby serving as an excellent green carbon-based carrier for heterogeneous catalysts. The synthesis of a functionalized chitosan@2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (CTT) carrier involves the reaction of chitosan with 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine in the presence of K2CO3. Following this, the [Cu]@CTT catalyst (Cu(OAc)2@chitosan@2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine) is prepared by using chitosan@2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine to react with Cu(OAc)2·H2O in acetone. The crude catalyst undergoes a simple filtration process, after which it is washed with water and dried under reduced pressure to obtain the purified [Cu]@CTT catalyst ( Scheme 2). Initially, chitosan (CS), 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine modified chitosan, and modified chitosan copper complex ([Cu]@CTT) were characterized using Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy to assess changes in the functional groups and molecular structure. The FT-IR spectra of CS exhibited characteristic peaks at 3427 cm−1 (O-H stretching vibration peak), 2906 cm−1 (C-H stretching vibration peak), 1590 cm−1 (N-H stretching vibration peak), 1378 cm−1 (C-H stretching vibration peak), 1252 cm−1 (C-O-C stretching vibration peak), and 1094 cm−1 (C-O stretching vibration peak as shown in Fig. 1 a). Compared to CS, the FT-IR spectrum of CTT displayed a new peak at 2151 cm−1, which is attributed to the C-N stretching vibration peak of 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (Fig. 1 b), indicating the successful modification of CS with 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine. Moreover, in the [Cu]@CTT spectrum (Fig. 1 c), new peaks at 3339 cm−1 and 1469 cm−1 were observed, representing the stretching modes of Cu-O and Cu-N bonds, respectively. This data supports the successful synthesis of [Cu]@CTT through covalent interaction, as confirmed by the spectral analysis. [16] The X-ray diffraction analysis was performed to investigate the structural regularity of [Cu]@CTT ( Fig. 2). The powder X-ray diffraction patterns revealed two distinct peaks at 16.2° and 32.2°, consistent with the reference pattern of α-Cu(OAc)2. To investigate the structural properties of the [Cu]@CTT catalyst, a nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm curve experiment was conducted. The results, as illustrated in Fig. 3, revealed that the [Cu]@CTT catalyst exhibits a characteristic IUPAC type-III adsorption/desorption behavior, suggesting the presence of a hierarchical porous structure within the catalyst. This behavior can be attributed to the presence of slit-shaped pores located between the chitosan layers. The specific surface area of the [Cu]@CTT catalyst was determined to be 32.1 m2/g. Additionally, the pore size distribution analysis of the catalyst, as depicted in Fig. 4, indicated that the majority of pores are concentered around 2.3 nm. This observation suggests that the [Cu]@CTT catalyst possesses a significant number of micropores, making it well-suited for facilitating the access of small organic molecules. The synthesized [Cu]@CTT catalyst was investigated using SEM and EDS analysis, as illustrated in Fig. 5. The scanning electron microscope captured various morphologies of [Cu]@CTT, revealing a surface with folds resembling a network structure. This unique surface morphology facilitates enhanced contact between the catalyst and organic small molecules. Furthermore, EDS analysis confirmed the presence of Cu, N, and O elements within the catalyst. The elemental surface composition and oxidation states of the metal components were determined using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). In the survey of XPS spectrum, peaks corresponding to Cu2p, O1s, N1s, and C1s were identified at binding energies of 933.3, 688.5, 529.9, 397.7, and 283.3 eV, respectively ( Fig. 6). A detailed analysis of the high-resolution Cu2p spectrum, as shown in Fig. 7, revealed peaks at 933.3 and 952.9 eV, which correspond to Cu1 2p3/2 and Cu1’ 2p1/2, respectively. The peak at 933.3 eV was attributed to Cu(II)-N coordination. [17] The presence of Cu2, Cu2’, Cu3, Cu3’, Cu4, and Cu4’ in [Cu]@CTT may stem from the varying Cu2+-chelating abilities of the functional groups within CTT. This observation provides evidence that the copper species have been effectively immobilized on the chitosan carrier. In the initial stage of the study, we attempted to use the synthesized Cu-based chitosan material ([Cu]@CTT) as the catalyst for the hydrophosphorylation reaction of alkynes with P-H bonds. To accomplish this, we introduced a catalytic amount of [Cu]@CTT (10 mg) into the reaction between diphenylphosphine oxide (1a) and phenylacetylene (2a), which was stirred at 100 °C in toluene under a N2 atmosphere, and supplemented with 2.0 equivalents of Et3N. The progress of the reaction, as monitored by GC and GC-MS analyses, led to the formation of the hydrophosphorylation product 3a in 66 % yield ( Table 1, entry 1). Various solvents including DCE, DMF, DMSO, CH3CN, 1,4-dioxane, THF, EtOAc, and MeOH were subsequently explored (Table 1, entries 2–9), with the optimal solvent being identified as 1,4-dioxane, yielding the E-configuration hydrophosphorylation product at the yield of 89 %. Screening of different base species such as DBU, DIEA, Cs2CO3, K3PO4, CH3COONa, and K2CO3 (Table 1, entries 10–16) revealed that the reaction performed best without the addition of any base. Notably, a reduction in the amount of [Cu]@CTT catalyst significantly lowered the yield of 3a. Omission of the [Cu]@CTT catalyst entirely resulted in no formation of the target product (Table 1, entries 16–20). Adjusting the reaction temperature from 100 °C to 40 °C led to a notable decrease in the desired product 3a; however, further temperature increment from 100 to 120 °C did not exhibit substantial effects on the reaction outcome. Consequently, the optimal reaction conditions entailed the use of diphenylphosphine oxide (0.2 mmol), phenylacetylene (0.2 mmol), [Cu]@CTT (10 mg), 1,4-dioxane (1.0 mL), N2 atmosphere, 100 °C, and a reaction time of 12 hours (Table 1, entry 16). The Cu-catalyzed E-selective hydrophosphorylation reaction can be utilized with various types of diaryl H-phosphine oxides, as demonstrated by the findings in Table 2. It is evident that when diaryl phosphine oxides contain electron-donating groups, such as di-p-tolylphosphine oxide (1b), di-m-tolylphosphine oxide (1c), bis(4-methoxyphenyl)phosphine oxide (1d), and bis(3,5-dimethylphenyl)phosphine oxide (1e), they can efficiently react with compound 2a under the optimized conditions, yielding the corresponding E-configuration hydrophosphorylation products 3b-3e in isolated yields ranging from 87 % to 91 %. Similarly, when electron-withdrawing groups are substituted in the aryl ring of diaryl H-phosphine oxides, as seen in bis(3-fluorophenyl)phosphine oxide (1 f) and bis(4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)phosphine oxide (1 g), the starting materials can be employed for the transformation, leading to the synthesis of target products 3 f and 3 g in yields of 86 % and 84 %, respectively. Furthermore, utilizing di(naphthalen-1-yl)phosphine oxide (1 h), di(naphthalen-2-yl)phosphine oxide (1i), and dibenzo[c,e][1,2]oxaphosphinine 6-oxide (1j) as substrates in the reaction also resulted in the successful synthesis of the desired hydrophosphorylation products, with yields ranging from 83 % to 88 %. The above case fully demonstrates that the presence of electron withdrawing or donating groups on the aromatic rings of most diaryl H-phosphine oxides does not significantly impact the formation of the target product in this conversion. In contrast, diethyl phosphonate (1k) and diphenyl phosphonate (1 l) did not exhibit reactivity in the reaction, leading to the absence of the corresponding hydrophosphorylation products (3k) and (3 l) formation post-reaction. As depicted in Table 3, a range of substituted alkynes (2b-2ad) were screened under the optimized E-configuration transformation reaction conditions. It is clear that aryl alkynes bearing electron-donating groups such as 1-ethyl-4-ethynylbenzene (2b), 1-ethynyl-4-propylbenzene (2c), 1-ethynyl-4-pentylbenzene (2d), 1-ethynyl-4-methoxybenzene (2e), and 1-ethoxy-4-ethynylbenzene (2 f) exhibit high reactivity toward the reaction, affording the expected E-configuration hydrophosphorylation products of 4a-4e in 88–93 % yields. When 4-ethynyl-1,1′-biphenyl (2 g) was employed as the substrate for the reaction, the corresponding product (E)-(2-([1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)vinyl)diphenylphosphine oxide (4 f) is generated in 87 % yield. Additionally, the electron-withdrawing groups substituted in the aryl ring of alkynes, such as 1-ethynyl-3-nitrobenzene (2 h), 1-ethynyl-3-fluorobenzene (2i), 1-bromo-4-ethynylbenzene (2j) and 1-bromo-3-ethynylbenzene (2k), they also showed satisfactory results, yielding the desired E-configuration hydrophosphorylation products 4 g-4j with 85–87 % yields. When 2-ethynylpyridine (2 l) and 3-ethynylthiophene (2 m) of heterocyclic alkynes were employed, the expected products (E)-diphenyl(2-(pyridin-2-yl)vinyl)phosphine oxide (4k) and (E)-diphenyl(2-(thiophen-3-yl)vinyl)phosphine oxide (4 l) could be produced in 83 % and 81 % yield, respectively. As expected, (prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene (2 n) was also appropriate for this transformation to afford the hydrophosphorylation product 4 m in 90 % yield. Additionally, 1-methyl-3-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene (2o), 1-methyl-4-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene (2p), 1-(tert-butyl)-4-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene (2q), 1-methoxy-4-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene (2r), 1-methoxy-2-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene (2 s), and 2-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)-1,1′-biphenyl (2t) were also showed satisfactory results, giving the desired hydrophosphorylation products 4n-4s with 82–89 % yields. When alkynes bearing multiple electron-donating groups, such as 2,4-di-tert-butyl-1-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene (2 u) and (3-methoxy-4-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)phenyl)methanol (2 v), were employed, the corresponding products (E)-(3-(2,4-di-tert-butylphenoxy)prop-1-en-1-yl)diphenylphosphine oxide (4t) and (E)-(3-(4-(hydroxymethyl)-2-methoxyphenoxy)prop-1-en-1-yl)diphenylphosphine oxide (4 u) were synthesized with yields of 87 % and 83 %, respectively. Additionally, alkynes like 1-fluoro-2-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene (2w) and 1-chloro-4-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene (2x) yielded the hydrophosphorylation products 4 v and 4w, with yields of 82 % and 86 %, respectively. Upon employing alkynes such as 1-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)naphthalene (2 y), 2-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)naphthalene (2z), 2-bromo-6-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)naphthalene (2aa), and 6-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene (2ab), the products 4x-4aa were obtained with yields between 86 % and 91 %. Lastly, the use of ethyl propiolate (2ac) resulted in the product of (E)-ethyl 3- (diphenylphosphoryl)acrylate (4ab) with 86 % yield. Notably,ethinyl estradiol (2ad) demonstrated good efficacy in the transformation, producing the hydrophosphorylation product 4ac with 81 % yield. As shown in Scheme 3, we investigated the reactivity of internal alkyne prop-1-yn-1-ylbenzene (2ae) with diphenylphosphine oxide (1a) under the standard conditions, which produced product 4ad in 86 % yield. In contrast, the use of 1,2-diphenylethyne (2af) as the substrate to react with 1a resulted in the formation of only a trace amount of the desired product 4ae. Instead, the main product obtained was 1,2,3-triphenylphosphindole 1-oxide (4ae’) in a 52 % yield. In order to demonstrate the practical application of this reaction, a large-scale reaction of diphenylphosphine oxide (10 mmol) with phenylacetylene (10 mmol) catalyzed by Cu@CTT was performed under the optimized conditions. After simple purification, the target product 3a could be generated in 83 % yield (2.53 g, Scheme 4). Recyclability is a key criterion for assessing the effectiveness of heterogeneous catalysts. The [Cu]@CTT catalyst has been found to exhibit exceptional recyclability in the regioselective hydrophosphorylation of alkynes, with minimal leaching of copper source (approximately 22 ppm based on ICP-AES analysis). Table 4 details the recycling test results with this catalyst, showing consistent yields of the desired product at 96–84 % after five cycles. To gain the insight of the mechanism for the selective hydrophosphorylation of alkynes with secondary H-phosphine oxides, some control experiments were conducted under the optimal reaction conditions as shown in Scheme 5. When the reactions were performed with the addition of two equivalents of the radical scavenger 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine N-oxyl (TEMPO) and 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol (BHT), the corresponding target product 3a were detected in 82 % and 93 % yields. These results suggest that the reaction may proceed not via a free radical process (eqs 1 and 2). Notably, diphenylphosphane (5a) was also showed positive results for this transformation, and provide the expected P-H addition product 6a in 86 % yield (eq 3). However, when we adopted diphenylphosphinic acid and water as the reactant to react with ethynylbenzene, to verify whether copper ions in the catalyst preferentially activate the terminal alkyne group in phenylacetylene by capturing by-products, as monitored by GC-MS, there is no other product formed during the reaction (eqs 4 and 5). The above experiment proves that during the reaction process, it is possible that the phosphoryl group coordinates preferentially with copper ions to initiate the hydrophosphorylation process. Under the optimal reaction conditions, we also explored the reactions of diphenylphosphine oxide with styrene (5c), but are still failed to from any new products in the reaction (eq 6). In order to clarify the transfer mechanism of hydrogen atom during the reaction, we selected Ph2P(O)D (1a’) as the substrate to react with 2a under the optimal reaction conditions. As monitored 1H NMR analysis, the hydrogen atom of olefin carbon in 3a’ was partially deuterated by Ph2P(O)D, a KIE (k H /k D ) constant was determined as 1.5 (eq 7). A plausible mechanism for this transformation is proposed as depicted in Scheme 6. First, phenylacetylene (2a) undergoes a reaction with the Cu-chitosan based catalyst, resulting in the formation of a reactive intermediate A. Subsequently, diarylphosphine oxide coordinates with the intermediate A, leading to the generation of intermediate B. The transfer insertion of the diphenylphosphine oxide component into the triple bond triggers the formation of a copper complex C. Following protonation, complex C transforms into D, which then proceeds to engage with another molecule of diphenylphosphine oxide and phenylacetylene. This binding event results in the generation of the anti-Markovnikov adduct product 3 and facilitates the regeneration of complex B. 4 Conclusion In summary, we developed a novel method for the anti-Markovnikov type regioselective hydrophosphorylation of alkynes with secondary H-phosphine oxides via a functionalized heterogeneous Cu-chitosan based catalyst. This approach avoids the use of highly toxic alkenyl halides, bases and oxidants, and a broad substrate scope of secondary H-phosphine oxides and alkynes containing different functional groups were tolerated well for this transformation. This method proceeds smoothly with heterogeneous Cu-chitosan based catalyst as the only additive, featuring recyclability as well as high atom economy in terms of green chemistry. The protocol also exhibits high potential for the construction of biologically active (E)-phosphoyl substituted alkenes and its derivatives. coredata.dc:description: The functionalized heterogeneous Cu-chitosan based catalyst was developed for the regioselective hydrophosphorylation of alkynes with secondary H-phosphine oxides. The functionalized chitosan framework was produced through a cross-coupling reaction between chitosan and 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine. Following this, the coordination of Cu(OAc)2 with the functionalized chitosan framework led to the synthesis of the heterogeneous Cu-chitosan based catalyst. Various techniques, such as powder FT-IR spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 physical adsorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), were employed to characterize the catalyst. Subsequently, the resulting Cu(OAc)2@chitosan@2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine catalyst exhibited remarkable catalytic activity in the regioselective hydrophosphorylation of alkynes with the formation of P–C bonds, displaying exceptional E/Z selectivity. This successful catalysis led to the synthesis of a range of (E) anti-Markovnikov adducts with high yields. The catalyst shows high recyclability in this transformation. On the basis of step-by-step control experiments, a plausible mechanism is proposed.
